g.text: Do Not Cite, Quote or Distribute
with small storage may be susceptible to climate variability, especially droughts, when the amount of
water may not be sufficient to generate electricity (see Section
Hydropower plants with storage may produce 10 GW, reaching over 100 TWh yr
uire large areas. Pumped storage hydropower stores energy by pumping water to higher
. The storage in hydropower systems provides
flexibility to compensate for rapid variations in electricity loads and supplies. The regulating
characteristics of the storage play an important role in assuring continuity of energy supply from
Hydropower is one of the lowest
operation and maintenance costs are typically 2
. Construction costs are site specific. The total cost for an installed
if the site is located far away from
transmission lines, roads, and infrastructure. Investme
nt costs increase for small hydropower plants and
or more for the installation of plants of less than 1 MW
80% more than for large hydropower plants
. During the past 100 years, total installed
costs and LCOE have risen by a few percent, but the LCOE of hydropower remains lower than th
Hydroelectric power plants may pose serious environmental and societal impacts (
. Dams may lead to fragmentation of ecological habitats because
for migration of fish and other land and water
borne fauna, sediments, and water flow. These barriers
can be mitigated by sediment passes and fish migration aids, and with provision of environmental flows.
Below dams, there can be con
siderable alterations to vegetation, natural river flows, retention of
sediments and nutrients, and water quality and temperature. Construction of large reservoirs leads to
loss of land, which may result in social and environmental consequences. Minimizing
environmental impacts requires taking into account local physical, environmental, climatological,
social, economic, and political aspects during the planning stage
large areas of land are flooded by dam construction, they generate GHGs
Maavara et al. 2020; Prairie et al. 2018)
. On the other hand, hydropower provides flexible, competitive
production in developing countries), and ancillary services such as municipal water supply, irrigation
and drought management, navigation and recreation, and flood control
long term economic benefits to communities affected by reservoirs are a subject of debate
Public support for hydroelectric energy is generally high
, and higher than support for coal,
gas, and nuclear. Yet, public support for hydro seems to differ for existing and new projects (
). Public support is generally high for small and medium scale hydropower in re
ionally, there is high support for existing
, where it is a trusted and
Public support seems lower for new hydropower projects
construction of new large hydropower plants has been met with strong resistance in some areas
. People generally perceive hydroelectric energy as clean and a
contributor to climate change and environmental pollution
Sweden, people believed that existing hydropower projects ha
ve as few negative environmental impacts
as solar, and even less than wind
. However, in areas where the construction of new large
scale hydroelectric energy is met with resistance, people believe that electricity generation from hydro
can cause environmental, social, and personal risks
